Dear ##first_name[Supporter]##,

Mobile Justice is the ACLU of Virginia's "people's bodycam" smart phone application. It allows users to send video of law enforcement interactions to the ACLU of Virginia for review, along with an optional but helpful incident report.

Get Mobile Justice today!

Given the alarming number of instances of police abuse across the country documented by victims or witnesses on their phone cameras, the need for the app is quite real. All too often private videos of police situations somehow disappear once someone's phone is confiscated. Worse, sometimes phones are damaged or destroyed.

Since the we launched Mobile Justice in 2015, more than 14,600 people have installed it on their devices and hundreds of videos have been submitted for review. Credo Mobile in 2016 selected Mobile Justice as one of the "top three progressive smart phone apps."

Useful features of the app include:

  • "Witness mode," which lets users know when someone else nearby is filming a law enforcement interaction so they can go to the scene and take their own video.

  • A handy "Know Your Rights" section to help users understand what they should and should not do during a police encounter.

  • Push notifications that let us alert you when there is an important criminal justice matter with which we need your help.

Yes, you do have the right to film the police. In addition to general use documenting the actions of law enforcement, we have found in this new era of protest that many people choose to use Mobile Justice at demonstrations and rallies to ensure that First Amendment rights are protected.

Most important, Mobile Justice is free and available for both iPhone and Android devices.

Get Mobile Justice today!

Sincerely,


Claire G. Gastanaga
Executive Director
ACLU of Virginia
